2.description: The room is silent. You feel about for the light switch. You find it, and gently press it on. Oops! It’s Mrs. Harding’s room! What a mistake! You see her turn and rise from the bedclothes, her frightened face screaming. As the scream pierces your ears, you hear the boarders begin to stir. The residents are coming! But what’s focusing your attention is the shotgun Mrs. Harding is reaching for. You’d better run!

3.description:
The Arkham First National Bank operates from 9 AM to 3 PM, Monday through Friday. If you're Professor Grunewald, the bank manager greets you personally, acknowledging your well-established account.

You may withdraw funds as needed, without any hassle. The atmosphere inside the bank is calm, with clerks attending to clients and the reassuring clink of coins echoing softly.
3.title: ARKHAM FIRST NATIONAL BANK

6.description:
There is a big difference between using a phrase book and speaking a language. You have real trouble in being understood or understanding what is being said to you.

You are going to need an interpreter—they speak English at the Athens Bureau of Investigation, perhaps you could find something there?

7.description: The window opens smoothly, and you enter. You try to move as quietly as possible.

choices.text: Try to run past the man

8.description: He takes your refusal without interest. 'Very well, sir. I shall return later.' He leaves and you stare at the walls of your silent room.

9.description: The man is an Egyptian. His posture seems threatening.

Attempt a DEX roll to preemptively act

11.description: Before you enter, you sense something beyond the door. Putting your ear to the door, you listen.

12.description: Food poisoning! You’re really sick! Make a successful Constitution roll and go on your way, or, if the Constitution roll is failed, spend three hours recovering, and lose 1 hit point.

success.message: You recover quickly and go on your way.

failure.message: You spend three hours recovering and mark off 1 hit point.

13.description:
For you, Professor Louis Grunewald, this first day of September 1931 has been tiring and uncomfortable. Light mist has covered Arkham for most of the day. You held two uninspired undergraduate classes at Miskatonic University, and you met with the new chairman of the literature Department, a giddy Technocrat. You survey your desk and see that a stack of papers to grade has already formed. You’re enjoying your second pipe of the evening, and putting off grading papers, when the doorbell rings. To your surprise, it’s a telegraphic messenger.

“It arrived at Kingspoint Head station not more than an hour ago,” the boy says.

You sign for it, and slip a dime into the youngster’s hand. “Oh, thank you, sir!” You open the envelope and scan the contents (see below).

My goodness, you think. Imagine! Dotty old Gliere in prison! You recall that he had gone to Greece to work on his book concerning primitive myths. What has he gotten himself into? Should you wire money? You recall all the amusing discussions you’ve had with him, and a sudden insight lets you understand that Tibor Gliere had no close friends except for you. Should you go help him? You suppose the University will grant you leave. But do you want to go?

With uncommon speed you decide to go to Athens to help Gliere. You write him a wire, and another to Ernest Holt, a wealthy New York financier and a good friend of yours. If you get into hot water, Holt will help, and so, you decide to keep him posted on your progress. You give both telegrams to the waiting messenger, along with the necessary funds.

What to do now? You’ll go to the bank first thing in the morning to get travel funds. As for Trans-Atlantic schedules, well the Advertiser surely carries that information. As you pack, you wonder if you should check Gliere’s room at Mrs. Harding’s boarding house. Maybe you could get a clue about Gliere’s activities or a hint about his arrest.

Your passport is in order; your clothes and sundries are packed. You’d best turn in. You’re going on a little trip. When you awake, it is Sept. 2.
13.title: START

14.description: You crouch in the gloomy shadows. Soon you hear slow, shuffling footsteps from many directions. Do you wish you’d run instead? Somehow you count yourself glad that you can’t make out the faces of the approaching figures—figures which move as though alive, and yet remind you of the dead! Now you’re sure they see you. You begin to panic.

choices.text: Use Fast Talk to get out of this

15.description: Nobody goes near the well-dressed driver. Perhaps there’s something odd about that. The old fellow looks shaky, but serene, while the young driver looks friendly, but perhaps overly brash.

16.title: ARKHAM DEPOT

18.description: At first, you move silently, cunningly evading the ghastly, lifeless figures which shuffle across the court in search of you. Then you clumsily kick a loose stone that clatters across the court. All of the terrifying figures turn toward you.

20.title: PIOSOTOS CAFE

As you enter the cafe, the thick, acrid tobacco smoke chokes you. The place is filled with laughing, gesticulating dockworkers and sailors.

It is bustling, but you don't hear any English being spoken.

Talk to the group in back playing cards

21.description: "And the Karpathos Device," you ask, "was it returned to the museum?" He shakes his head. "Oh, no. It was scheduled to be sent to the National Museum in Cairo for a special exhibit. The Device may be Egyptian, you see. The plans were not changed."

22.description: Christos whispers to you, suggesting that you and he could just burst into the office. He grins slyly.

choices.text: Agree and burst into the office

23.description: “Don’t try and flim-flam me! This is my boarding house and I’ll allow in whom I wish!” She slams the door.

choices.text: Try sneaking in later at night

24.description: This constellations map is quite similar to the copy of Ptolemy’s found in the Miskatonic University collection. Strangely enough, the star patterns here are slightly twisted or even completely skewed. In fact some stars are missing completely.

25.description: “Aristotle Mylonas, while collecting an undeniably tremendous treasure house of Greek art, has been reluctant to loan or even to show some of the National Museum’s most interesting treasures. The Karpathos Device, for example, has not been displayed for years. Its loan to other museums is, according to Mylonas, unthinkable.”—Great Museums of the Modern World.

26.description: As you enter the hotel, something gives you pause. You hesitate for a moment, noticing strangers in the lobby who seem to watch you. One of the strangers seems to hide his face.

success.message: You notice the strangers watching you.

failure.message: You fail to notice anything unusual.

27.description: Something grabs you. You must struggle to escape.

success.message: You tear yourself free from the grasp and escape.

failure.message: Another thing grabs you, and you must fight against their combined strength.

28.description: The door is locked, but you can try the window. If you want to pick the door lock, make a successful Locksmith or Hard Mechanical Repair roll. If you want to pry open the window, succeed at an STR roll.

choices.text: Pry open the window with an STR roll

29.description: You see strange, bird-like markings and some scribbled words in the Professor’s familiar hand. Three of the words seem paired with the symbols—'old', 'heavens', 'cold'.

choices.text: Attempt to decipher the markings with an INT roll

30.title: GREEK CONSULATE
30.description: Concerning Greek criminal matters, they advise visiting the Athens Bureau of Investigation on arrival. A Corporal Ilionas, they say, has handled the Gliere case. You ask for information about the National Museum and its treasures, but they have only an unhelpful travel brochure. They jokingly caution you about the cab drivers of Athens.

choices.text: Go to any New York Location

31.description:
Despite your best efforts, the dark figures continue to advance. You are surrounded and reaching hands grasp you, closing around different parts of your body, tighter and tighter. You whimper and then scream. The last thing you see is a nightmare of hollow eyes; the last thing you smell is the stench of fetid, hungry mouths. It is . . .

THE END.

32.description: In rifling through Gliere’s notes and letters, you find a portion of manuscript: “The Great Upheaval Myths Correlated with Climatic Change” by T. Gliere. Skimming, you see a bizarre collection of tales mentioning nearly every rumored land, from Atlantis to Mu. Many stories you do not recognize at all. Apparently, Gliere sought historical and physical evidence for these sunken and frozen legends of lands. He seems to have found common dates for the devastation myths found in nearly every culture. Interesting.

choices.text: Attempt to Spot Hidden details in the manuscript

33.description:
Trembling with fear, you reel down the road from the Parthenon. You spy a lone figure ahead, a white-haired old man who uses a walking cane. You babble a warning in English, supposing that the alarm alone in your voice will be enough to dissuade him from going closer to the horrors lurking in the Parthenon behind you.

To your surprise, he answers in English. His voice is slow, but it inspires your confidence. “Fear no more,” he says. “Tonight the stars themselves bind those things to the top of the sacred hill. We have nothing to fear here.”

Your terror begins to lift like a veil. “Your friend was killed by one of those... creatures. You see them in museums, you know, looking like stuffed animals. Undead? Ghouls? Who knows their origin? Your friend Gliere saw them just before they killed him. That is as much as you and I need know.” He pauses. “Our lives we struggle in darkness. We are poor beings, who need the darkness in order to find the light.” As he says these words, the moon breaks through the clouds, and a calm beauty pervades the world. Your fears are quenched, your heart utterly at peace.

“I have been on quests like yours. I have been a scholar of the unusual. I know the uncertainties and the terrors. There is nothing we mere mortals can do but strengthen our faith and struggle against the darkness.” The two of you walk slowly.

“I do not know what Gliere had discovered. But I do know that while in prison he told someone that if the Karpathos Device was returned to its home, life as we know it will cease to exist.”

He turns to you, “I am at the end of my life. It is up to you to stop this evil, as your friend attempted so valiantly. Egypt is the answer. Go there, find the Karpathos Device, return it to the sea, or destroy it utterly.” He takes something from his hand. It is a ring, heavy with gold, curiously made, covered with signs, most prominently a five-pointed star with a core of flame. “I give you this. It has power, though perhaps not as much as you would want. Use it against dead things brought back to existence.”

For a moment a friendly hand has steadied you and restored your resolve. This warmth of feeling is what you fight for—and the numbing terror which chased you from the hill is what you despise.

When you look up again, your new friend is gone. The road is empty. The encounter was like a dream. But the ring is still there. You slip it on a finger; it fits firmly and comfortably. Reaching the bottom of the hill, you find a cab and go to a hotel. You sleep peacefully.

addItem.name: Ring of Power
addItem.description: A ring heavy with gold, covered with signs, most prominently a five-pointed star with a core of flame. It has power, particularly against dead things brought back to existence.

34.description: Despite your best efforts, she will not change her mind and sends you on your way.

choices.text: Return to the main area of the museum

35.description: The man is Richard Hawkes. He greets you warmly. "An ouzo and some talk," he suggests. "Look, I know you’re investigating Gliere’s death. I’ve talked to him once or twice. His death caused quite a stir. Well, to make a long story short, I have some interesting information concerning his crazy theft. I don’t have it here, but if you’d like to come back to my apartment, I can show it to you."

choices.text: Agree to go to his apartment
Schedule a meeting at the Parthenon at sunset
Go to any New York Location

36.description: Something is wrong. You learned long ago to trust your hunches. Grunewald’s telegrams stopped without explanation 72 hours ago; your inquiries have gone unanswered. Should you alert your agents scattered across the globe? Judiciously sipping superb brandy, at last you decide against the employment of proxies. Grunewald hinted of mysteries beyond the capacities of mere assistants. You trust his judgment and decide to go yourself. You scrawl instructions to subordinates and dictate phone messages to a secretary whom you have callously woken from a sound sleep. Your holdings will tend themselves for a few weeks. Your passport is in order. You’ll pull strings to get an assortment of visas overnight: mere governments cannot keep Ernest Holt from aiding a friend. A liner sails soon. Jenkins can have you packed and ready to go in an hour. You have plenty of time. It’s a pity your experimental trans-Atlantic passenger plane isn’t quite ready, though that would be fun! You find yourself eagerly anticipating action in the field. You feel ready for anything. You call Lydia Lau at The New York Sun. A despicable rag of a newspaper, but a crackerjack young lady with lots of talent. Miss Lau has heard nothing from Grunewald. You notice her professional interest grow as you talk, and you ask her to write nothing for a few days. “I’m sure there’s a proper explanation,” you say grandly, but somehow you know that neither of you believes that statement. Now you sleep. You’ll attend to details tomorrow. When you wake, go to any New York Location.
36.title: ERNEST HOLT’S APARTMENT

choices.text: Go to any New York Location

37.description: You flirted with the City Editor, and then polished up the National Editor. As usual, your skills and your baby-blues got you what you wanted, and you don’t mind giving an old goat a lift now and then. Besides, this could be the biggest story of your young life, or so you hope. Headlines sail through your imagination: “MISKATONIC MYSTERY!” “GAL GUMSHOE TRACKS DOWN MISSING PROFESSOR!” “FINANCIER FOUND ALIVE!” And your by-line is under every one. With Gliere dead, and Holt and Grunewald missing, you’re pretty sure that the story behind this one will be a real jaw-dropper— and probably dangerous. Holt’s been missing for 72 hours. You thoughtfully pack the gigantic revolver given to you by Bruno the vice-squad cop. A girl can’t be too careful, you decide. You can leave soon on one of the regular liners, and in the meantime do some shopping and research—maybe even make a trip to Arkham. You send a telegram to your beau, Devon Wilson, aboard the USS Rochester, telling him your plans and that you’ll keep in touch. The Sun’s circulation boost from this story should blow that pipsqueak Daily News right out of the water, you dreamily calculate. As for you, it’ll be goodbye New York—hello Pulitzer Prize! In the morning, go to any New York Location.
37.title: Lydia Lau's Apartment

38.description: This retailer accepts currency from any country.
38.title: RETAIL STORE

39.description: You hear a scream. The plane lurches, then tilts slightly to the right. You notice that the previously smoothly flying craft has begun to wobble.

40.description: "But yes, very strange . . . Professor Gliere first stealing that device, then taking his own life. I wish I could tell you more. The Karpathos Device is mysterious. No one knows its true nature. Perhaps the scholars at the National Museum can tell you about it."

41.description: Attempt the appropriate Language roll for each of the following books. For each successful roll, spend two hours and go to the pertinent entry:

choices.text: Attempt a German roll for 'Die Mythe'
Attempt a French roll for 'Cultes des Goules'
Attempt a Latin roll for 'Liber Ivonis'
Attempt an English roll for 'Marvels of the Spirit World'

42.description: You board the train and are faced with a choice of accommodations. The crowded, smelly seats are certainly the more affordable option, but far from comfortable. Alternatively, you can pay for a private suite, complete with a toilet and basin, offering some privacy and comfort for the journey.

43.description: The plane has been abandoned, but it looks in good condition. A tempting thought enters your mind: steal it.

choices.text: Check out the plane and get it started

44.description: The cockpit door is slightly ajar. You push it open. Beyond the cockpit door sprawls the limp, lifeless body of the pilot. You see the futile kicks of the co-pilot. The plane flies on, tentatively. The Arab turns his head. You gasp at the sunken, ghostly eyes. His skin has a grayish pallor. He looks like an animated corpse.

choices.text: Engage in combat with the Arab

45.description: “That’s just fancy talk! I know your sort! Professor Gliere specifically instructed that no one disturb his room.” She slams the door.

choices.text: Try sneaking in later at night

46.description: Curious, you think. That symbol looks almost like a map (see image below). You take the notepaper with you.

choices.text: Take the notepaper and continue your investigation

47.description: A new steward enters, carrying fresh towels for your stateroom. He looks Egyptian.

choices.text: Get some rest and wake up tomorrow morning

48.description: “Aristotle Mylonas, Director of the National Museum of Archaeology in Athens, died today in a bizarre automobile accident. His car, apparently going much too fast, spun through the railing of a stone bridge across the Illissus River. This internationally known scholar, largely responsible for the protection of many Greek national treasures, will be sorely missed. A reclusive man, Mylonas was unmarried and without other family. He declared always that his beloved Greece was both mother and father to him.”—Arkham Advertiser, July 1, 1931

49.description: You find a piece of notepaper with a curious design.

choices.text: If successful and you also have a gun, go to the pilots’ cabin

51.description: Suddenly, Mrs. Harding appears. “Why the idea!” She sputters. “I’ll count to three,” she says, her grip tightening on the shotgun she’s pointing in your general direction, “and then I’ll pull the trigger! One… two…” You quickly decide to leave.

52.description: You've managed to enter the Harding House without causing too much disturbance. Now, you must navigate quietly.

53.description: You find a letter from a Mr. Velikovsky, postmarked Palestine. The scrawl is difficult to read, but you can see that the author greets Gliere’s work 'with joy.' There is a page about the Vedas and how they confirm something called the 'Polar Reversal.' One portion deals with the 'Era of Fertility on the Frozen Continent.' Velikovsky reports that work on 'Freudian Heroes'—including Ikhenaten—continues.

54.description: Three floors of books! Some titles interest you. You have enough suitcase room for no more than three.
54.title: E.S. WILENTZ BOOKSTORE

56.description: You can take individual cab trips, but it's far better value to book a cab for the day.

choices.text: Go to any New York Location

57.description: Jacques smiles gallantly, "I am trying to interest wealthy Greeks in the romance of the air. But my little service has not been well received, mmmh? Yet perhaps I may take you somewhere?"

choices.text: Accept Jacques' offer to fly you

58.description:
You see three drivers standing near their cabs. One is young, another is an old man, and the third is nattily dressed. Which will you hire?

If you can successfully make a Psychology or a Spot Hidden roll, then go to 15 first, then choose.

59.description: Something’s not right. You can, if you are carrying a weapon, get it ready.

60.description: You can look up scheduled sailings. You notice a newspaper with news of Athens. For each hour spent browsing through the paper’s back-issue files, you can attempt one of the following rolls once.
60.title: ARKHAM ADVERTISER

61.description: You notice flakes of dry skin; someone has left behind his or her sunburn, you think. Quite out of place to do it in this fine shop. You look around and see two figures, one short and one tall, staring directly at you. You quickly leave the shop.

62.description: The ancient myths refer to Gotterdammerung, the fall of the Gods. Inexplicably, almost all of these Northern myths say that the climate became colder after that fall.

63.description: This democratic nation of freedom-loving peoples has a complex and lengthy history. They are fiercely protective of their rights, and even more protective of the precious artifacts of their heritage.

64.title: BOSTON RAILWAY STATION
64.description: There are trains to New York City’s Grand Central Station and Arkham. Should you miss the train, you have friends in Boston who will gladly put you up for the night for free. You can then catch your train in the morning.

choices.text: Take the 10am train to New York (arrives at 5pm)
Take the 4pm train to New York (arrives at 10pm)
Take the 10am train to Arkham (arrives at 11am)
Take the 1pm train to Arkham (arrives at 2pm)
Take the 6pm train to Arkham (arrives at 7pm)
Stay overnight in Boston and catch a morning train

65.title: NEW YORK SUN (EUROPEAN EDITION)
65.description:
When you browse through the newspaper, you notice three items:

"Amet Keh, Director of the Cairo National Museum, eagerly awaits the arrival of the Karpathos Device, on loan from Athens."

"The casket bearing Professor Gliere, the academic thief from Miskatonic University, has been placed aboard the Urania for New York. A memorial service has been scheduled in Arkham, Mass., U.S.A."

"The Starkweather-Moore Expedition nears readiness as The Dark Sea heads for Bremen, Germany. Once there, final preparations include reinforcing the hull for the treacherous journey into the ice floes surrounding Antarctica."

67.description: Her eyes are wary, but she is listening.

69.description: Two foreigners stand on deck. The tall fellow wears a robe with a cowl. He is perhaps Arabic or Turkish. A shorter fellow, ferret-like, looks in your direction. Though they seem out of place on this ship, they make you feel uncomfortable.

70.description: “The myth of the cataclysm, or the upheaval, is one of the oldest tales and is found in nearly every culture. These imagined events occurred, according to some Nordic myths, three or four thousand years ago. Other legends, notably those told by the Shikastra sect of Tibet, date the world-changing disaster to as recently as 850 BC.”—T. Gliere, The Destruction Myths.

71.description: Astonishingly, the skin has the unmistakable look of the preserved flesh of an Egyptian mummy.

72.description: You find a map of the heavens, resting on one of the shelves.

73.title: FIRST SUNDAY
73.description: You are enjoying your first Sunday on the ship.

choices.text: Notice anything on the Ship's Tour?

74.title: NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY
74.description:
While not allowing browsers, the helpful librarians provide a selection of books on a topic. They are busy and understaffed, so only two topics may be researched per visit. You may go to another location and then return here in the same day.

No rolls are needed for these books. It takes two hours to study each topic.

75.description: After a long, cramped, and uncomfortable three-day journey, you finally arrive safely. The train offers further connections that could take you onward to Istanbul, Damascus, and eventually Cairo.

76.description: The Arab’s hand has an eerie, grayish pallor. Claw-like, it grabs the door latch to the pilots’ compartment.

77.description: Your interpreter tells you, "Gliere hung himself, he killed himself. Yes, his body has been shipped to the United States. Apparently the Professor left nothing behind to be recovered."

79.description:
His small apartment is cluttered with books and filled with rich aromas. It is the room of a scholar.

You will now attempt several rolls to uncover more about this situation.

choices.text: Attempt Knowledge, Cthulhu Mythos, Occult, Spot Hidden, and Listen rolls

80.description: “In a gala ceremony, Zeno Pisistratos was installed as curator of the National Museum of Archaeology at Athens today. Pisistratos, an expert in Greek and Egyptian antiquities, is said to be interested in arranging exchange-exhibits with other important world museums.” —Arkham Advertiser, July 20, 1931.

81.description:
"I’m Christos. Where to?" You tell him and he’ll take you anyplace in Athens. Along the way he says, "Listen, I’m a great interpreter. If you need help with Greek, you couldn’t do better than me. Fifty drachmas a day: I stay with you, drive you around. Like a guide. What do you say?"

Weighing his character, you think there’s some chance that he’ll abandon you and do a little celebrating on his own as you go from one point to another. But probably he can interpret just fine, and he seems to know where to go.

82.description: The MU library is open 9am to 9pm, Mon-Sat.
82.title: MISKATONIC UNIVERSITY

83.description: The ship is bustling with activity.

84.description: A chapter notes that the most bizarre case of 'undead' occurred among French Legionnaires in North Africa. Outpost guards were found strangled with flecks of dead, scaly skin still sticking to their throats.

choices.text: Continue looking over the Occult books
Return to the New York Public Library

85.description:
"Egypt today is an engaging mixture of ancient and modern. Camels and marketplaces are side-by-side with motorcars and luxurious hotels. Religions of various kinds play a special role in Egypt, some of them of a most unusual nature. It is best, for example, to avoid the cult of Aten, a mysterious and perhaps dangerous group found in the major cities of Cairo and Alexandria."

—Baedeker’s Guide to Egypt

86.title: NEW YORK SUN
86.description:
“The oft-delayed Starkweather-Moore expedition to the Antarctic nears completion, with a late December departure now virtually certain. Bremerhaven, Germany, will be the expedition’s jumping-off point, and its last European port of call.”

“An American professor, Dr. Tibor Gliere of Miskatonic University, has been arrested for the alleged theft of an antiquity. Miskatonic’s Dean Wilcox reports that a colleague, Professor Louis Grunewald, has gone to Athens to investigate the matter for the University.”

choices.text: Go to any New York Location.

87.title: ATHENS HALL OF JUSTICE
87.description:
The Hall of Justice and the King’s Court of Appeals are open from 9am-noon, and from 3pm-7pm, Mon-Fri.

If Christos is with you, he knows exactly where to go; if you are alone, you spend an hour before you arrive at the right corridor and find the desk sergeant in charge of the jails. The sergeant speaks no English.

choices.text: Spend some time looking for someone who speaks English

88.description: While formerly fashionable, avant-garde has become politically suspect. The occult is faddish with many of the younger politicians. Various readings and portents are said to promise a bright future for the Fatherland.

choices.text: Continue your research into other topics

89.description: Mrs. Harding glares and slams the door in your face.

choices.text: Sneak in later, when everyone is sleeping

90.description: The boarding house is quiet. You creep onto the porch.

91.description: Something glistens beneath his open jacket, troubling you.

92.description:
He will take you to Cairo or Bremen, with no questions asked. In order to have daylight to complete the trip, he must take off before noon.

The flight will be a windswept adventure in an open-cockpit biplane. "Ooh lah lah!"

93.description: You turn in for the night, the rhythmic clatter of the train soothing your mind as you drift off.

94.description: You are lost somewhere in the great desert of North Africa. Your water will last for a little while. Your water supply will be tracked above. Each time you go to another entry, your water total will decrease. When you run out of water, you will lose 6 hit points each time you go to another entry. You will be safer when you reach other humans. You start walking. The heat is incredible, but you must go on!

effects.description: Your initial water supply is set.

95.description: “Professor Gliere’s suicide has shocked and saddened the Miskatonic academic community. No word has yet come from Professor Grunewald.”

choices.text: Go to any New York Location.

96.description: While you enjoy painting on deck, you notice one of the female passengers quietly weeping. As you move to offer her comfort, you are transfixed by what she is painting: strange, stalk-like creatures standing in a weird landscape of oddly-angled buildings bathed in purple light. The creatures seem to be screaming, though they have no visible mouths. Horrified, you move away without saying anything.

98.description: The plane’s engine roars into life. You smugly taxi down the runway and head the craft expertly into the wind. You give her the throttle and the plane hurtles down the tarmac and into the air. You’re airborne!

99.description:
As you enter the passenger compartment, a steward in a blue uniform offers you a piece of chewing gum and some cotton.

He gestures that the cotton is for your ears. You take one of the wicker seats in the plane. As you look out toward the terminal building, you see two brutal-looking men intently watching the plane. As your face comes into their view, you see them point and smile. If you think you shouldn’t be on this flight, you can return to the airport entry.

If you stay aboard, you see other passengers file in: a number of Arabs, an Englishman energetically chewing his gum, a Greek tycoon, and a colonel in the Greek military. The thud of the corrugated aluminum door is met with the screeching whine of the engines springing to life. A fitful roar fills the cabin. The attendant stands in back as the plane sails smoothly into the sky.

As you head south, the cabin is much colder than you imagined it would be, even though you’re quite near the heating ducts.

“Chew your gum!” the Englishman shouts above the din. “The gum! It will help your ears!” You smile and signal OK.

After a while, one of the Arabs gets up and moves to the front of the cabin. He is a tall fellow, moving slowly. The steward moves forward, perhaps to direct him to take his seat. The toilet, if that is his goal, is in the opposite direction. The Arab opens the cockpit door.

100.description: The Dean shakes his head, 'Out of the question, Grunewald. I already have that young dolt Perkins covering for Gliere. And now you want to leave? Not a chance, sir.' Does the Dean leave you no choice?

choices.text: Forget the whole business and let Gliere fend for himself

101.title: MODERATE HOTEL
101.description: This hotel offers a clean room and a quiet night of sleep.

choices.text: Go to an Athens location in the morning
Go to an Alexandria location in the morning
Go to a Cairo location in the morning

103.title: CAIRO TAXIS
103.description: On the few main streets of Cairo, cabs of every variety, from sleek new Packards to old Fords running on makeshift parts, can be found.

choices.text: Hire a driver for the day

104.title: PIER 56: CUNARD LINES
104.description: The representative informs you that a liner departs each Saturday at noon, reaching Athens at noon nine days later, and Alexandria at 1pm one day later. Tickets are available and include all meals.

choices.text: Take the Saturday noon liner to Athens (arrives nine days later at noon)
Take the Saturday noon liner to Alexandria (arrives ten days later at 1pm)
Go to any New York Location

105.description: The sailors talk about some kind of curse, which they say is leaving Greece. You also hear that the Kyonas, an ocean-going motorship, is for hire.

106.description: The small man pulls out a dagger and swings it toward your midsection with alarming speed, but it misses and sticks into the wall. Meanwhile, you can retrieve a weapon (if you carry one) or you can run.

failure.message: The stranger lets loose a shot as you fail to dodge.

107.description: You make out "Gliere," and then a word like "strangled." Then the men stop talking and look up at you.

108.description: You’re assigned a battered black Peugeot and a bright-eyed young Egyptian. He speaks some English but has no particular interest in your mission.

4-10.description: You arrive safely a few days later.

109.title: FIRST MONDAY
109.description: You are enjoying your first Monday on the ship.

110.description: Some of the wonderful devices were said to open secret chambers or panels in the tombs. These chambers were thought to be in places that looked like solid rock. No intact device has been found, though, nor have any such chambers been discovered.

111.description: The film today is Alfred Hitchcock’s Murder. You look forward to seeing the film and feel that young Hitchcock is a promising director.

choices.text: Watch the film and make a Listen roll

112.description: You have a bad feeling about this.

choices.text: You passed your Occult or Cthulhu Mythos check
You passed your Spot Hidden check

113.description: Mrs. Harding greets you amiably. She is uncertain whether she should show you Gliere’s room.
113.title: HARDING HOUSE

114.description: The officer says that the Karpathos Device is gone. As for who took it, there are only rumors and if you wish to seek such rumors out, you should head to the Fuzira Marketplace.

115.description: You ask the purser about the foreign pair seen on deck. 'Egyptian, I believe. Rather a strange lot, I’d say. Haven’t been giving you any trouble, have they?' You thank him and leave.

116.description: It is suggested that the Karpathos Device found in 1900 is in fact of Egyptian origin or design, but was, for some reason, stolen. In fact, some scholars have argued that it is one of the “wonder devices” of the Aten pyramids.

117.description: There is an etching of a supposedly enchanted symbol (see image below). You think the drawing important, and copy it down.

choices.text: Return to the New York Public Library

118.title: NATIONAL MUSEUM OF ARCHAEOLOGY
118.description: To look around the museum, you can visit the exhibits or try to see Pisistratos, the Museum Director. After November, he is on vacation.

choices.text: Try to see Pisistratos, the Museum Director

119.description: The friendly natives of Micronesia seem to have some deep-seated fear of an angry god who will rise from the sea. British sailors, seeing the odd idols throughout the islands, named the god 'Old One-Eyed Reilly.'

choices.text: Continue your research into other topics

121.description: You see the book Nameless Cults, in the Golden Goblin Press edition. You thumb through it—vile stuff, you decide. Something about this book alarms and fascinates you and you spend an hour reading it over. Gain +3 Cthulhu Mythos skill points for your initial reading. You take the book with you.

122.description: His eyes narrow when he hears your news. 'Gliere in jail? And you want to go rescue him? You’d best talk to Dean Wilcox.'

choices.text: Don’t talk to the Dean, go to the library

success.message: You hear footsteps outside your door.

failure.message: There's a sudden commotion at the door and the handle turns.

124.description: They are Egyptian hieroglyphics. Make a successful Language (Hieroglyphics) roll.

125.description: “Greek sponge divers have recovered a puzzling device off the island of Karpathos, a small island between Crete and Turkey. The device is a mechanism believed to be thousands of years old, yet bright and untarnished, as though made yesterday. Scientists have declined comment on the metal from which the device is made. Archaeological experts from the National Museum have taken possession of the oddity for further study.”—Arkham Advertiser, June 8, 1900.

126.description: You are enjoying a beautiful day on the ship.

choices.text: A group seems to be gathering

127.title: EXPENSIVE HOTEL
127.description: This is the best class of hotel. It has 24-hour room service.

1-8.description: Nothing unusual happens during the night. You wake up refreshed.

128.description: It’s on a ship right now, bound for Cairo.

129.description: The asp poison is strong. You can feel it coursing through your veins, and time is running out.

success.message: You feel like you are fighting off the poison.

failure.message: The poison surges through your body.

130.title: ATHENS BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION
130.description:
You quickly locate the office of the investigator in charge of Gliere’s case, a Corporal Ilionas. After a few pleasantries, his words stun you.

"Sir, I regret to inform you that Professor Tibor Gliere is dead by his own hand. He has hanged himself. Perhaps he was too ashamed of his theft of the Karpathos Device from the museum. We do not know. But yes, a suicide. A sad end."

Your mind reels. You have come all this way, to no purpose. You cannot believe that Gliere would end his own life, even though his career was in jeopardy. Is Ilionas positive?

"You suspect foul play? No, that is not reported. The pathologist found signs of self-mutilation, common enough with suicides. What? Oh—the doctor is vacationing in Switzerland. He will not be back for weeks." The Corporal considers for a moment. "You can see Gliere’s cell, I suppose, unless someone new has been moved in. He was held at the Hall of Justice."

choices.text: Ask for more information about the case
Ask about getting a Greek interpreter
Take a cab to any Athens Location

131.description: A slender, dark-haired young fellow calls out, "Hey, English! Taxi! Anywhere in Athens, five drachmas!"

133.description: What a splendid ship! You have all the comforts of a big city within a few hundred feet of your cabin: beauty salon, fine men’s clothing, jewelry, sporting goods, books, etc. You decide to look at some new gloves.

success.message: You successfully spot something interesting.

failure.message: You don't notice anything unusual and continue your day.

134.title: FUZIRA MARKETPLACE
134.description: The market thrives from early morning to after sunset. There are hundreds of shops and stalls. Many signs are in English, and many British troops idly walk around. You can choose from among the following:

135.description: As you walk down a corridor, you feel uneasy. Attempt a Spot Hidden roll to see if you notice something strange.

failure.message: You fail to notice anything unusual and continue walking. Suddenly, there is movement to your side and a small man rushes at you.

136.description: A Cunard liner departs Pier 56 in New York City every Saturday for Athens and Alexandria, with intermediate stops. The trip takes nine days to Athens and one more to Alexandria.

137.description: You hear two people coming down the row of seats and sit behind you. Entering, you noticed that the theater was nearly empty.

choices.text: Attempt to escape with a DEX roll

success.message: You successfully get out of your seat and out of the theater. Continue about your day.

failure.message: You fail to escape in time.

138.description: Your mind reels as you see all the areas you could study. Three in particular seem of interest.

choices.text: Go to any New York Location

139.description: Just at that moment, one of the ship’s officers enters, distracting the thing—allowing you to get away! The officer, his hair standing on end, wisely turns on his heels and runs with you down the hall to safety. The captain has you guarded for the rest of the trip; no sign of your attackers are found. You have no more ship activities selections.

140.description: You read the following: 'Where is the Lost City of the Old Ones? Where are the treasures of the Eldritch Masters? Cursed are they, condemned by the shoggoths to lie buried, waiting in the ice, for one more turn of Aten’s Top.'

choices.text: Continue looking over the Occult books
Return to the New York Public Library

141.description: You hear thunderous snores. This room is occupied and can’t be Gliere’s room; you better try a different door.

142.description: “Martini, straight up, please.” He turns to you. “I couldn’t help but notice, old friend, that some strange people seem to follow you. A word of advice: stay off the deck, suspect everyone, stay out of the library and other lonely spots. I’ve seen these assassin types in action, by God.” You have never seen him before. He then talks about chess for a while, finishes his martini, and leaves. You never see him again.

143.description: Dr. Fen shakes his head, “I wish I could be of help. Perhaps our Dean, Dr. Wilcox, can tell you what you want to know.”

144.title: CAIRO POLICE
144.description: Affable enough, they have no information concerning what you want to know. If it is after October 31, you may learn more.

choices.text: One of the officers seems interested in you.

145.description: For each hour at Miskatonic’s library, you may attempt one of the following actions.

146.title: GRAND CENTRAL STATION
146.description: If departing for Boston, there are two departures for Boston every day. One leaves at 8am and arrives at 3pm; the second leaves at 6pm and arrives at 12:30am. From Boston you may connect with a local train for Arkham. Wait here for your train, or go to any New York Location.

choices.text: Take the 8am train to Boston (arrives at 3pm)
Take the 6pm train to Boston (arrives at 12:00am)
Go to any New York Location

148.description: You are enjoying another gorgeous day on the ship.

choices.text: Who is that person over there?

149.description:
The museum closes at 9:00 PM.

Much open-minded learning and studying occurs in this incredible Cairo institution. Lately, the presence of British troops makes many Egyptians reluctant to talk with foreigners.

You can visit the library or one of the departments within the mosque-like main building. Each visit costs one hour, though additional time may be demanded in certain departments.
149.title: UNIVERSITY OF AL-AZHAR

150.title: Professorial Study
150.description: You enter and cautiously turn on a light to see a room in proper professorial confusion. Scattered about are books of myths and fables, and there are bundles of clippings from various foreign newspapers. For each hour you spend here, you can attempt one roll for one of the following skills. Each skill may be tried once daily.

choices.text: Sneak out with a Stealth roll

151.description: The window gives way, and you tumble from the train, hitting the ground hard. You lose 3 hit points. At the next stop, you are forced to wait 24 hours for another train.

152.description: You attempt to jump or dodge past the snakes. Your survival depends on your agility.

success.message: You successfully leap past the snakes and make it to safety.

failure.message: You fail to jump in time and are bitten by the snake.

success.message: You successfully dodge past the snakes and make it to safety.

failure.message: You fail to dodge in time and are bitten by the snake.

153.description: A young secretary guards the door to the Museum Director’s office. She informs you in careful English that Mr. Pisistratos’ schedule is full.

choices.text: Argue with the secretary to see Pisistratos
Return to the main area of the museum

154.description: Many private homes, from huts to mansions, have rooms to let to visiting tourists. They are very safe.

failure.message: Nothing seems out of the ordinary.

choices.text: Spend the night, then explore Cairo
Spend the night, then explore Alexandria

155.description: The library is deserted. Well, peace and quiet is just what you crave. You’re examining the newest Agatha Christie novel when a short, sullen-looking fellow enters the room, followed by a tall man wearing a cowl. You nod uneasily and then return to your book, uncomfortably aware that they are moving nearer. You look up again. The short man smiles, and pulls out a gleaming dagger.

choices.text: Draw your weapon (if you have one)

success.message: You quickly draw your weapon before the attacker strikes.

failure.message: You fail to draw your weapon in time and the attacker strikes.

success.message: You manage to dodge the attack and try to escape.

failure.message: You fail to dodge and are struck by the dagger.

156.description: “DEC. 20, BREMERHAVEN – The Starkweather-Moore expedition departed today under clear skies and calm seas. Despite the record cold temperatures, many came to the pier to see off the expedition.”

157.description: You read about the Top of Aten, a rumored relic from the period of Akhenaten. The top, a magical device, in some sources is mentioned as the cause of the Old Kingdom’s fall. It was Akhenaten who came to possess it and who (some scholars hint) worshiped the ancient evil ones who designed it. Akhenaten’s strange disfigurement is said to have been caused by his meddling in bizarre magical rites.

choices.text: Continue looking over the Occult books
Return to the New York Public Library

158.description: You have one chance to fire before the things pull you off-balance and into the pit. Despite the range being point-blank, the darkness is overwhelming. You fire and hope for the best.

1-5.description: You successfully hit and wound one of the ghasts. They retreat and fade into the darkness.

6-10.description: You miss your chance to fend them off, and they pull you into the pit.

159.description: It is said that the spirits of the Pharaohs haunt the pyramids, and that some unfortunates even have seen them.

choices.text: Continue looking over the Occult books
Return to the New York Public Library

160.title: MOTORSHIP KYONAS
160.description: A peeling but sturdy-looking vessel rests beside the pier. It is the Kyonas. On deck, you see a sign: "SHIP FOR HIRE - see Capt. Miko Rduka." If you want a secret way to leave Greece, this might be it. Rduka, the half Armenian and half Greek captain, will take you anywhere in the Mediterranean. It takes 24 hours to get the vessel loaded, fueled, and crewed.

choices.text: Hire the Kyonas to sail to Alexandria

161.description: You get specific directions to the Fuzira Marketplace. Two alternate names for the marketplace run through your mind: 'The place where anything can be lost or gained,' and, 'the place where souls are bartered.' You idly thumb through the volume. You think you would like to go to Egypt.

162.description: “You have wandered into something beyond your wildest dreams,” he says. “My friends wish to help you. Find out what you must, then meet me at the Parthenon at sundown.”

163.description: “Instances of ‘Dementia Antarctica’ have been experienced by many parties exploring the frozen continent. The most recent and vivid account was rendered by the disaster-plagued journey of Lake to the unexplored northwest regions. The bizarre reports even shocked people familiar with the phenomenon. The rescue party succumbed to the isolation and cold, and all survivors spent months in sanitariums babbling about lost cities and subterranean horrors. Recently, specialists have suggested that an enriched diet will prevent such terrible delusions.”

choices.text: Continue your research into other topics

164.title: HOTELS
164.description: Space is a bit tight, but you must get a room. Take your chances to see how you fare.

1.description: You feel uneasy with where you ended up, but at least this place is a roof over your head.

2.description: You feel uneasy with where you ended up, but at least this place is a roof over your head.

3.description: You feel uneasy with where you ended up, but at least this place is a roof over your head.

4.description: It's not much, but you are in luck.

166.description: You see Pisistratos, the Museum Director, showing the museum to an English dignitary. You rush up to him and quickly ask your questions. He briefly speaks but seems to want to dismiss you, saying he doesn't know why Gliere stole the antiquity. He also says that it's normal for loans, such as that of the Karpathos Device, to be made. Finally, he states that the Karpathos Device is a type of clock.

choices.text: Make a Psychology roll about Gliere

success.message: You detect something is off about his answer regarding Gliere.

failure.message: You don't notice anything unusual.

choices.text: Make a Psychology roll about the loan of the Karpathos Device

success.message: He seems uncertain about the Karpathos Device's loan.

failure.message: You don't detect any hidden motives.

choices.text: Make a Psychology roll about the Karpathos Device being a clock

success.message: There seems to be more to this 'clock' than he's saying.

failure.message: You can't tell if there's more to his explanation.

choices.text: Return to the National Museum of Archaeology

167.description: You hear a knock at your cabin door. 'Cabin steward, sir. May I make up the room?'

choices.text: Tell the steward to come back later

168.description: The archaeological team at the National Museum in Athens have reported on the Karpathos Device, noting the inexplicable markings on its surfaces and the complex network of gears and linkages. The team has established that the Device is at least 2,000 years old, although some suggest it might hold a more ancient date. The report implies an ancient level of technical achievement previously undreamt of by scholars. Cryptic Greek inscriptions were found on the outside edges of some gears, while some interior sections were marked with unusual Egyptian hieroglyphics. The team makes no guess about the function of the Device.

169.description:
You recall that Aten, the sun god, became the center of the new monotheistic cult founded by Akhenaten. The strange practices begun by the Pharaoh became more bizarre as the young ruler grew more deformed.

You ponder your adventures so far, thinking about the events that have brought you here.

170.description: After 2 hours of waiting around, Evgenia, an interpreter, is found for you. If you wish, you are able to hire Evgenia for the length of your stay.

171.description: You are reflecting on your activities for the day.

172.description: Tibor Gliere’s suicide stunned Miskatonic University. The disappearance of Professor Grunewald under suspicious circumstances has set rumors flying. Dean Wilcox is puzzled, upset, and unwilling to give an interview, but his secretary confides that Dean Wilcox hasn’t a clue as to what is going on.

173.title: ATHENS HARBOR (PIRAEUS)
173.description: Approaching the coast, you see that it is similar to that of New England, with oddly-shaped inlets, gulfs, and headlands. But New England is cool, moist, and green; here, luxurious golden warmth pervades everything. The Greek republic, only seven years old, totters under the hardships of the worldwide depression. The people are eager for tourists, as foreign money is much needed. Your ship docks at the gaily-decorated harbor at Piraeus. Higher up in the hills beyond, Athens gleams beneath the midday sun. Many black automobiles bear the word 'taxi' hand-lettered on their sides.

choices.text: Take the Tuesday or Friday 3pm ship to Alexandria (arrives in 24 hours)
Take the Tuesday or Saturday 4pm ship to Bremen (arrives in 5 days)
Take the Friday Noon ship to New York (arrives in 9 days)
Take a cab to the Bureau of Investigations

174.description: The Karpathos Device is in Cairo at this moment.

175.description: Your host understands that you’re a scholar of some sort, and he acts scared. You question him, and you glean the words "Aten," "door," "open," and then he leaves with an anxious prayer upon his lips.

failure.message: Your host seems hesitant to speak further and you feel very tired.

choices.text: Sleep soundly and explore Cairo in the morning
Sleep soundly and explore Alexandria in the morning

176.description:
You see the fabulous treasures of ancient Greece. You also find the stand where the Karpathos Device, replaced at the moment by a drawing and a photograph, is normally kept.

The notes speculate that the Karpathos Device is some kind of astronomical clock designed to aid priests. Other scholars feel it may have been designed to actually create something material. Still others see it as merely an elaborate amusement for some wealthy noble or merchant. The origin of the device is uncertain, and the substance of which it is made has not been determined.

choices.text: Learn more information on the Device.

177.description: You push past the secretary and burst into Pisistratos’ office. He stands up, blinking. "This is an outrage," he sputters in excellent English. Christos leaps upon him and pushes him back into the chair. "Ask your questions boss," says Christos.

choices.text: Ask him why Gliere stole the device
Question him about the loan of the Karpathos Device.
Ask about the Karpathos Device being a clock

choices.message: You both run out of the office, leaving Pisistratos shouting curses at you.

178.description: The Karpathos Device has arrived safely in Cairo for an extended display. Curator Amet Keh is reported as thrilled to have it on loan.

choices.text: Go to any New York Location.

179.description: The young fellow takes you wherever you want to go.

180.description: The man appears afraid. Pressing him further, he admits fear, "I don’t think Gliere killed himself. Someone wanted him dead. Someone or something! I don’t know … It had to do with the Karpathos Device. Gliere kept saying that it must not go to Egypt."

181.title: ATHENS AIRPORT
181.description:
At the tiny airport, three aircraft sit beside the airstrip. A Douglas M2 mail plane, ten years old and looking it, rests alone. A Ford TN-Motor waits in front of an open hangar. A Fokker T-2, a strange bird with its snub nose, has a mechanic working on it. You notice a single bystander who seems to watch you intently.

Inquiries at the office reveal that the TN-Motor makes regular flights to Cairo. It leaves at 8am daily. The mail plane is not delivering mail anymore. The pilot, Jacques Risee, sits in the tiny bar.

The clerk says that the Fokker is unavailable, but if you want, you can look it over.

choices.text: Buy a ticket and return for the next TN-Motor flight to Cairo
Talk to Jacques Risee at the bar

182.description: You find the symbol of the cult of Aten (see image below), the so-called Egyptian death cult. You think that you may have seen that shape before.

choices.text: Continue looking over the Occult books

183.title: ATHENS RAILWAY STATION
183.description:
The train to Istanbul, Damascus, and finally Cairo leaves daily at 12 noon. It takes three days to make the trip. The train north to Vienna and then to Bremen leaves daily at 9am, and takes three days to arrive.

You notice that a man looks up from his newspaper and studies you intently.

184.description: Preparations are said to continue apace for the Starkweather-Moore expedition to Antarctica. The expedition will retrace the steps of the ill-fated Lake-Douglas party. The new expedition sets sail in December, from Bremerhaven.

choices.text: Continue your research into other topics

185.description: Two figures enter: a short man holding a wicked-looking dagger and a tall man dressed in a shadowy cloak. The short man lunges at you with a dagger. You must act quickly.

choices.text: Make a DEX roll to ready your weapon

success.message: You manage to draw your weapon just in time!

failure.message: The short man lunges with his dagger before you can react.

186.description: “Oh. Resign? Ahem. My dear fellow, I apologize! I should have recognized how serious you were. Go! Save poor Gliere’s hide. I know you’ll do it speedily and judiciously. The University will certainly pay for your round-trip ticket.” As you leave, you hear footsteps move quickly away from the door. But when you look out, the hallway is empty.

187.title: CUNARD SHIP ACTIVITY TABLE
187.description: The CUNARD liners are truly luxurious, with spacious rooms in nearly every class, remarkable recreation facilities, and superb cuisine. While you are aboard the liner, suspend hourly record keeping, but keep track of days. Resume hourly record keeping when you disembark at Athens or Alexandria.

189.description: As you exhibit your prowess with a skeet gun, you hear a soft pop! Hearing a bullet whine past your ear. You wheel around. No gunman is in sight. The other shooters have not noticed the gunshot. Despite their stares, you abruptly leave the competition.

190.description: The disappearance of the Karpathos Device and of Amet Keh baffles the Egyptian authorities. Mr. Pisistratos of the National Museum in Athens will not comment.

choices.text: Go to any New York Location.

191.description: An ornate mirror catches your eye. What appears to be mere filigree around the border proves to be a frieze of snarling animals of some kind.

failure.message: You can't help but to look into the mirror.

194.title: THE PARTHENON
194.description:
The majestic temple columns glow golden-yellow in the setting sun, deepening to blue as you clamber across the rubble to reach the lonely inner court. The beauty of the scene somehow oppresses you, and gradually you sink into your own thoughts. As you ponder the suicide of Gliere, a scream abruptly brings you to the present. The cry seemed to come from nowhere.

Suddenly you are aware of your isolation and vulnerability in the deepening gloom.

195.title: ALEXANDRIA HARBOR AND RAIL STATION
195.description: The docks and rail station are near one another, surrounded by a web of narrow streets filled with shops and cafes. If you've just arrived in Egypt, you can stay in Alexandria for a night and find an excellent room.

choices.text: Go to dockside cafes and entertainment
Catch the 10am train to Cairo (arrives in 1 hour)
Catch the 1pm train to Cairo (arrives in 1 hour)
Catch the 6pm train to Cairo (arrives in 1 hour)
Take the Wednesday or Saturday 3pm ship to Athens (arrives in 24 hours)
Take the Thursday noon ship to New York (arrives in 10 days)
Take the Monday or Friday 4pm ship to Bremen (arrives in 144 hours)

196.title: CAIRO AIRPORT
196.description: Around the airport you detect an odor resembling manure. You also see many British troops. A few planes are scattered about the tarmac. Regular flights are available on a Ford Tri-Motor and on a smaller (but steadier) Northrop Alpha.

choices.text: Take the 3pm flight to Athens (arrives at 6pm)
take the 9am flight to Bremen (arrives at 5pm)

197.description: He has had no word. First Gliere, now this. He shakes his head.

198.description: You ask your host if they speak English.

success.message: "I do speak English," your host says with a slight British accent.

failure.message: Your host responds something in Arabic.

199.description: "It is bad to be here now, sir. A most dangerous object has come back to our land and an ancient curse will be fulfilled."

failure.message: Your host seems to be too frightened to be charmed.

choices.text: Try to Fast Talk your host

failure.message: Your host seems to be too frightened to be bribed.
Your host seems to be too frightened to be persuaded.

choices.text: Rest and explore Cairo in the morning
Rest and explore Alexandria in the morning

200.description: "The ancient door of Aten will open and the 'Top That Turns the World' returns to the blasphemous pit from which it came. Then once more our land is green, but your world disappears!"

201.description: The old man questions you about your visit. He seems almost suspicious.

choices.text: Get out of the cab and get another
Instruct the driver to be quiet and take you where you want

202.description: He hesitates. "Yes", he says, "Gliere was hanged, but his body and face were disfigured strangely. Huge welts ran down the length of the Professor’s body. To Ilionas’ eye, he looked like he’d been long dead before his neck was stretched."

203.description: As you sit at the bar, an elderly man nods to you and quietly asks if he may join you.

choices.text: Allow the man to join you

204.description: You ask to see Ilionas’ report. It says that Gliere refused to talk freely, but that he made libelous statements about Museum Director Pisistratos, and that he pleaded that the Karpathos Device not be sent to Cairo. It also notes that Gliere demanded protection even while he was in his cell.

205.title: CAIRO RAIL STATION
205.description: You can get a good meal here between 5am and 8pm. An offensive odor, like the scent of manure, hangs over the station. Many British soldiers prowl about the area.

choices.text: Take the 12 noon train to Alexandria
Take the noon train to Athens (3-day trip)

206.title: CAIRO MUSEUM
206.description: The museum is open 9am to 6pm daily. Three exhibits in this great museum might interest you:

207.description: You notice a picture bearing the label, “Akhenaten’s Amulet.” You make a sketch for your notes.

208.description: The symbol displays a strange mucous-like creature, covered in eyes and mouths—it looks like a shoggoth! A hideous monster capable of transforming its great mass into all manner of tools and shapes.

209.description: The Karpathos Device is there, with interesting background information. Its appearance is remarkably modern, resembling aluminum but obviously of great strength. Its enclosure is electrically guarded to prevent theft. Need a refresher on the Karpathos Device?

choices.text: Refresh your memory about the Device.
Back to the main area of the museum.
Explore other ideas about the Device.

210.description: You come to the Nile! After splashing in its refreshing waters, you follow the great river north. Catching rides with some engineers and then some archaeologists, you arrive in Cairo in 2 days.

211.description: Having come so far and seen much danger, you believe the fate of the world might depend on your actions. How could you not attempt to secure the Karpathos Device?

choices.text: Hide until the museum closes and then attempt the theft

212.description: You decipher four words from the hieroglyphics: 'ones,' 'spin,' 'city,' and 'top.' The rest baffle you.

choices.text: Attempt a History roll to understand more

213.description: With a successful Navigate roll, you know where you are. If you fail the roll, you can wait for someone to pass by or walk for a day in a chosen direction.

success.message: You know where you are.

failure.message: You are still lost.

214.description: These desert lands all begin to look the same. Have you been going in circles? Should you change directions? Drink one day’s water, then choose a direction.

215.description:
The museum closes at 9:00 PM.

You are dazzled by the flowing robes of the scholars and the dramatic stairs twisting to upper floors. To use the treasures of information here, spend one hour per Library Use roll, for as many hours as you wish. With one successful roll, you discover something valuable; with two successful rolls, you gain even deeper insights. You must stop when the library closes, but you can return tomorrow.

choices.text: Attempt a Library Use roll (1 hour)

failure.message: You find nothing of interest, but you can try again.

choices.text: Return to the university main entry

216.description: Professor Jahark will need to be convinced that he is not wasting time with you. You can try one roll daily:

failure.message: You fail to persuade him, but you can try again tomorrow.
Your fast talk fails, but you can try again tomorrow.

choices.text: Return to the university main entry

217.description: Professor Jahark sees you if you can make a successful Persuade or History roll. Choose either one (make one try daily); if you succeed, you may proceed. If you fail, you'll need to try again another day.

failure.message: You fail to persuade him, but you can try again tomorrow.
You fail to convince him with your knowledge of history, but you can try again tomorrow.

choices.text: Return to the university main entry

218.description: "O my heart, rise not up against me as witness." Beside this sentence, a scholar long ago annotated, "This reveals the undead’s fear of discovery. That is partly the reason for suppressing sections of the book, this guide to reviving and controlling the mummy in its new earthly existence. There is no solution, however, for the grayish deathly pallor to the skin, nor for the drying skin flakes which peel away so easily."

219.description: You hear many stories about making money and about losing it. When you mention Cairo, they show no interest.

220.description: Is that something there crossing the desert?

success.message: You meet a friendly caravan and travel to Cairo in 2 days.

failure.message: It must have just been a mirage.

221.description: You are able to get a small meal. There are several groups of locals huddled about the area.

choices.text: Attempt to talk with the locals

222.description: A narrow tunnel joins two streets. You welcome the coolness. Suddenly, you hear someone behind you say, "Kaieeee! In the name of Aten!"  The voice screams as a curved blade misses your neck by a fraction of an inch.

failure.message: You fail to evade the attacker, and he swings his blade at you. You must now fight to survive!

223.description:
“May I be of assistance?” the man asks. “I too was once a stranger in this sacred land. My temporary employment allows me to stay here while I work on my book. Where can I take you?”

He is Richard Hawkes. He will take you wherever you want to go, all the while chatting amiably about the splendors of Greece. He hints that he knows something you wish to know, and tells you to meet him at 6pm at the Piostos Cafe.

224.description: The darkness is terrifying. You stand undecided for a while.

225.description: You can ask about the cult of Aten or the Searchers for the Lost Pyramid.

choices.text: Ask about the cult of Aten
Ask about the Searchers for the Lost Pyramid
Return to the university main entry

226.description: The corporal is friendly, but nervous. You can tell that he is unconvinced by the death report. Something scares him, but he only mutters that he is glad the Karpathos Device has left the country.

choices.text: Try to Fast Talk the Corporal

failure.message: The corporal is having none of it and sees you out of the building.
The corporal is having none of it and sees you out of the building.

227.description: A narrow tunnel joins two streets. You welcome the coolness. Suddenly, you hear someone behind you. You prepared yourself for action, but then two policemen enter the tunnel ahead of you. The footsteps stop, then retreat: when you turn, you see only the fringe of a white robe going around a corner. You return to the hotel, unmolested.

choices.text: Depart for Cairo in the morning

228.description: He turns to the door and locks it.

229.description: The Karpathos Device is secured within a thick glass enclosure with an alarm system. What do you do?

231.description: "Not Aten, sir. It goes by many names in the old books: Lord of Mu, Master of the Deep … But here," and he pulls down an old book, "here it is called Ghatanothoa. Even this rough sketch is horrid. That thing they worship. And it is said to seek a new kingdom." He smiles. "Of course, it is all rubbish, you understand."

232.description: The burning desert sands have no end. Subtract another day’s water for this ordeal. Are you losing confidence? Do you want to change direction?

233.description: "Few now truly believe that creatures travel between our plane and the Netherworld."

234.description: You’re a born navigator! You figure correctly that you’re west of Cairo. In one day you enter the Giza suburbs west of the city.

235.description: If you could just get your bearings, you might know where you are.

success.message: You know where you are.

failure.message: You are still lost.

236.description: A cut-away model of the Pyramid of Akhenaten is on display.

failure.message: You fail to discern anything.
Your luck does not reveal anything.

choices.text: Make a successful Cthulhu Mythos roll

failure.message: You fail to recall anything useful.

237.description: In his book-lined office, you can ask Professor Jahark about all of these topics:

choices.text: Ask about the cult of Aten
Ask about the Lost Pyramid of Akhenaten
Ask about the Book of the Dead
Make a Spot Hidden roll (Professor Jahark's 50% skill)

failure.message: You notice nothing out of the ordinary.

choices.text: Finished? Return to the university main entry

238.description: If you make a successful Luck or Know (EDU) roll, you say something that catches Professor Emu’s attention.

failure.message: You fail to catch his attention, but you can try again tomorrow.
Your knowledge doesn't seem to impress, but you can try again tomorrow.

choices.text: Return to the university main entry

239.description: Professor Khargeh, an expert in ancient and modern languages, offers you insight into the linguistic history of Egypt. He shares details about several dead languages that are only partially deciphered, along with modern dialects that have evolved from ancient roots. He explains that many ancient texts, especially those from the time of Akhenaten, contain layers of meaning lost to time. He warns that certain symbols and phrases, when spoken aloud, are said to have unsettling effects on those who understand them.

choices.text: Press for more details about these 'unsettling effects'

241.description: Your attacker falls heavily to the floor. You spend the night unmolested in the hotel. In the morning, you decide to head for Cairo.

242.description: In the arid wastes you come across a trail!

success.message: There is a caravan is approaching! They’re going to Cairo, and you’re saved!

failure.message: You see a caravan in the distance, but it is moving away from you! In your weakened condition, you can’t hope to catch it. You collapse beside the trail, weeping.

243.description: "Brought back as undead, these mummies return to earthly service devoid of human feeling or compassion. Dark evil grips their souls. Reportedly, only fire or removing their tana leaf life-essence can destroy them."

244.description: In a series of friezes, you notice that a strange, mucous-looking creature has been partly chiseled away. The creature seems to resemble the ancient slave race of the “Old Ones” you’ve read about in dubious tomes of lore. You think you remember the name given to them: shoggoths.

245.description: The next day you see a city on the horizon. Desperately you stumble toward it. The domes and minarets suddenly begin to tremble and disappear—a mirage! You were foolish to have imagined a city in the desert. Drink another day’s water ration and choose a direction.

246.description: You draw up just in time. Another few steps and you would have fallen a hundred feet into that ravine! You must get a grip on yourself. Drink another day’s water ration and choose a direction. And be careful!

247.description: Your jaw drops. The Karpathos Device, a placard informs you, has been stolen.

248.description:
"Sir," says Ilionas, "I have told you all I know. You must go. All that’s left are rumors, and they’re better obtained at the Piostos Cafe."

You skulk the hallways of the Bureau for a while, and find nothing.

250.description: Your quick thinking and talking has the desired effect.

251.description: "From the book of  "What Is In The Netherworld" we can see engraved on the tombs of the 19th and 20th Dynasty kings, the grotesque creations of the perverted priestly imagination, which finally gained credence in the highest circles."

252.description: The exposed interior of the pyramid is much too small. There must be something else in there.

253.description:
You locate a couple of books, which look interesting. If you can make a successful Language roll, or have an English/Arabic dictionary and make a Knowledge roll, you can examine the following books. Each attempt advances time by 1 hour.

• A version of "The Book of the Dead" (Arabic)
• "Alhazred and the Curse of Egypt" (Arabic)
• The "Mysterium" (Latin)
• "The Lost Pyramid" (English)

If you know these languages, you could just read them, or if you have picked up a dictionary, you can use that. If you failed to read the books, you may return and try again on another day.

choices.text:
Make a Language (Arabic) roll to study

*The Book of the Dead*

failure.message: You struggle with the text and may try again another day.

choices.text:
Use your phrase book to read

*The Book of the Dead*

failure.message: You cannot fully comprehend the text.

choices.text:
Make a Language (Arabic) roll to study

*Alhazred and the Curse of Egypt*

failure.message: The book's meaning eludes you for now.

choices.text:
Use your phrase book to read

*Alhazred and the Curse of Egypt*

failure.message: You cannot fully comprehend the text.

choices.text:
Make a Language (Latin) roll to study

*The Mysterium*

failure.message: You fail to decipher the Latin text.
You cannot fully understand the text and may try again later.

choices.text: Return to the University of Al-Azhar main entry

254.description: You come to a great body of water. It is the Mediterranean Sea! Soon you find a railway track and hitch a ride to Alexandria aboard a section gang handcar.

255.description: The towering yellow sand clouds sweep over you, and you seek shelter from the fury in a nearby gully. The storm lasts the rest of the day. When you emerge, you see nothing you can recognize. Disheartened, you drink another day’s water ration and decide to choose a direction of travel.

257.description: Maybe you can figure out how to orient yourself, otherwise you are going to need to keep walking.

success.message: You succeed in your Astronomy roll.

failure.message: You fail to navigate using the stars or knowledge.

choices.text: Attempt or Hard Know (half EDU) roll

success.message: You succeed in your Hard Knowledge roll.

failure.message: You fail to navigate using your knowledge.

258.description: At the Fuzira Marketplace you can join a caravan, hire help, and hear rumors of every sort.

259.description: It makes no difference where you are, or how you came to be here. You're sleeping, tossing and turning, twisting the sheets into taut ropes around your body. You dream of creatures oozing putrid liquids from holes scattered across their amorphous bodies. You see the holes open and close, and then you silently scream as you see a morose, hungry eye resting within each hole, and hundreds of mouths filled with serrated teeth. Shuddering, you wake up. In the brief moment of sanity left to you, you see that you were not dreaming and not asleep in bed! It’s all really happening! You are being eaten! It is undoubtedly … THE END.

260.description: You can ask Professor Ben 'Ozen about the Karpathos Device, or return to the university main entry.

choices.text: Return to the university main entry

261.description: The literature professor is quite willing to talk of many things:

choices.text: Ask about the cult of Aten
Return to the university main entry

262.description: "Our fathers tell us that the disasters were great across the civilized lands, and into the barbarous reaches beyond. Snow fell where none had been, and grass grew where ice once gleamed. Many who survived perforce must have learned new ways. Awful prayers were said, and horrible gods took power. Who could tell the good man from the bad? All learning and respect for tradition ceased."

263.description: In the dim yellow night-lights of the museum, you can scarcely believe your eyes. The place has come alive with undead in many forms: from human mummies to megatheria in the natural history wing, all bizarrely returned to life! Everywhere you see the ominous, jerky shuffle of half-dead things. Instinctively you understand that these entities want to snuff out your life and baffle your purpose. You edge quietly along the halls, intent upon your escape from this hair-raising peril. To escape, you need to make successful Spot Hidden, Dodge, and INT rolls respectively, without missing any of the rolls.

264.description: A once popular novel, one eerie sequence tells of deadly creatures pursuing the hero down strangely-twisting corridors. He protects himself against the creatures, which are not of this Earth, by touching a magic amulet and receiving help from a god called only the 'Ancient Master.'

265.description: "The cult is very old, with origins attributed to Akhenaten himself. Cult practices led to perversions and oddities, partially prompting the Pharaoh’s downfall. I suggest placing extra guards at key locations, and ignoring their so-called holy place at Tell-el-Amarna, an unimportant tomb. The murder cases will remain open, though I doubt we’ll find the culprit who left behind such a strange calling card."

266.description: He shakes his head. "I really don’t know what it could be for, nor I hazard does anyone else."

choices.text: Return to the university main entry

267.description: "This is the demented scholar who led the rebirth of the cult, though the seed had slept there down through the millennia, waiting for a foul spurt of evil to give it rise. Now the cult performs its evil rituals throughout the land, worshiping not Aten but the evil ones who pose as his priests."

268.description: You stumble and fall as fractured rock gives way beneath you; you incur a sprained ankle and lose 2 hit points from bruises and cuts. Perhaps you should throw away your water and end the torment now. The situation seems hopeless. But you resolve to struggle until the very end. You choose a direction and drink a day’s water ration.

269.description: In a cleft of a ravine you find a pale white flower, the only thing growing for miles. It seems the most beautiful plant you have ever seen. You salute it, and take courage from it.

270.description: He laughs bitterly. "No cult, my friend. ‘Cult’ makes it sound understandable. And they do not belong to Aten. What can I say of them? They are murderers perhaps, ghouls more likely, but the merest pebbles under the feet of their master."

choices.text: Finished? Return to the university main entry

271.description: "It might be an astronomical clock, or some kind of lock, or it could work as some kind of coordinating mechanism for a greater device—about which we know nothing."

272.description: He speaks passable English. To ask him about:

choices.text: Ask about the cult of Aten
Ask about customs regarding travel, hiring help, etc.
Return to the university main entry

273.description: "Yes, they have grown more active. The authorities hush it up, but in the past few years tremendous numbers of inhabitants have disappeared."

274.description: Police cars come screeching up to the museum. You have several options, and should think about them all before choosing one:

choices.text: Talk your way out of this
Persuade them that you belong here
Admit your actions to the police

275.description:
The musuem closes at 9:00 PM.

This is an excellent library! In little time, you locate five "more" pertinent books. To use each, you must succeed with the correct language roll, or employ a translator. One hour is required for each book:

• The "Pnakotic Manuscript" (Latin)
• Col. F. Dupont's "Le Culte d'Aten" (French)
• "Die Goules" (German)
• "The Pharaoh's Curse, A Novel" (English)
